data.title: Delaware County police memorial service in Rose Tree Park
data.meta_description: Delaware County police memorial and DA happy not to be adding another name after recent shootouts
data.text:
Deadlines:

Monday-Friday 8:30am-4:00pm, Call 610-915-2226

(Proofs will be provided for accuracy only, they will not be styled/formatted like the finished product)

Obituaries submitted on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays are accepted from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. by email only Obit@delcotimes.com

(No proofs will be furnished. Pricing will not be available until the next business day after 10:00am by calling Dianne at 610-915-2226)

Obituaries received after Deadline will not be published in the following edition of the paper.

Sending Procedure:

Email is the preferable method for receiving Obituaries (and the only method on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays), they can be sent to Obit@delcotimes.com (Feel free to call and confirm that we’ve received the email)

Formatting:

Obituaries will continue to visually look the same as they currently do, but you will no longer be restricted in what you can say (ex. As much Family can be listed as you’d like; Wording like “Went to rest with the Lord” is now permissible)

Other:

There is a cost for each obituary. Pricing and payments are only available Monday through Friday, 8:30 am to 4:00 pm. All weekend and holiday submissions will be provided a cost the next business day.

Exceptions:

All New accounts, Out of State Funeral Homes and Private Parties will require prepayment upon approval of the obituary. Weekend and Holiday staff are not authorized to set up a new account or process payments

Deadline for the above is before 4:00 PM Mon – Fri. only (Holiday schedules may vary).

Prepayment required submissions will be handled on the very first business day following the weekend and/or holiday schedule. A complete name, address and best contact phone number are required upon submittal of your obituary request to set up your account. A proof will then be emailed for review but placed on hold until payment is received.

On the day Delaware County law enforcement annually honors those lost in the line of duty, officials were thankful not to be adding any more names to their memorial in light of all the incidents of officer-involved exchanges of gunfire this year.

“I am thankful we are here remembering those who lost their lives and adding a plaque to this memorial,” District Attorney Jack Stollsteimer said Wednesday. “Thanks to the grace of God we are not adding a more names here today.”

The Delaware County Law Enforcement Memorial Foundation’s annual Police Memorial Service was held Wednesday at the memorial in Rose Tree Park.

He cited Chester detective Sgt. Steven Byrne, East Lansdowne Officer Rob Meehan and Lansdowne Officer David Schiazza who carried the memorial wreath during the ceremony. Each man was shot in two separate incidents in February, Byrne in the later incident and Meehan and Schiazza in the earlier.

Byrne was shot after a police pursuit. He was investigating a drive-by shooting when he exchanged gunfire with a suspect, who was killed.

Meehan and Schiazza were injured in the shootout part of the shootout and fire that resulted in six deaths in East Lansdowne, including the perpetrator.

“That massacre that horrible day in East Lansdowne was also county law enforcement’s best day,” the DA added. “The police response, everybody working together regardless of their own personal safety.”

Stollsteimer said an uplifting aspect of the East Lansdowne tragedy was the silent majority of residents who reached out to him to say they were thankful for police officers and the officers were in their prayers.

“They know for us to have a just society we need to have a component of law and order. It’s the only way it works,” Stollsteimer said. “And thank God there are many men and women like those … who keep answering the call of duty to serve our community.”

Stollsteimer lamented that the professional criminal class has access to firearms that sometimes outgun police. He also said there are too many people who have mental health issues who have access to weapons.

“We need to do more as elected officials, as a community to stand up and make sure our officers have every single tool they need to protect us,” he said.

Stollsteimer said he is horrified to hear from officers how many guns are recovered from simple traffic stops and how that prevents another massacre.

The memorial foundation honored 47 fallen officers.

Family of fallen heroes, law enforcement officers from across Delaware County and their families and friends attended.

The service began with officers carrying individual uniform hats to the spot of each of the fallen officers, followed by a ceremonial “roll call” of the 47 names of the fallen officers that are displayed on the memorial wall.

The Rev. Perry Messick, the FOP chaplain, reminded those in attendance that the 47 and all police officers protect us from the forces of evil.

Delaware County Council President Dr. Monica Taylor thanked officers and noted when each of them take a call they are risking their lives running towards danger.

“You are truly heroes,” she said.

Originally Published: May 8, 2024 at 2:10 p.m.
